To a shepherd unpractis'd in art,</br>Ye maids of Parnassus incline;</br>To him your assistance impart,</br>Whose tribute is laid at your shrine.</br>Tho' dull and ungenial the day,</br>Bright Pity appears in the vale,</br>The sportsmen her mandates obey,</br>No longer the coppice assail.

Nor longer with spaniel and gun,</br>In dress which the bramble defies,</br>Accusing the slow-rising sun,</br>To cover young Doriland hies.</br>The pheasants beneath the rude thorn</br>In safety their plumage may spread,</br>Or venture to pilfer the corn</br>The hand of Rusticity shed.

No dangers the covey annoy;</br>Securely the partridge shall pair,</br>And taste of each warm sunny joy,</br>As Phoebus impregnates the air.</br>But Mercy is partial; for lo!</br>Black perils await on the fen,</br>The snipe feels the death-levell'd blow,</br>Which the woodcock destroys in the glen.

To scenes of more softness I speed,</br>The muse in her pastoral flight,</br>Come, Flora, enamel the mead,</br>Replenish the earth with delight:</br>Conceal not your mantle of green,</br>For nature's cold bosom is bare,</br>You purpose to clothe the dark scene,</br>The snow-drop alone can declare.

The snow-drop, young blossom, how chill'd,</br>Cold herald, with winter in rear,</br>Thy veins seem with isicles fill'd,</br>Pale gift of the unripen'd year.</br>If other weak flow'rets are found,</br>They scent not the spiritless day,</br>They breathe not an odour around,</br>Are neither inviting or gay.

Should clouds in succession descend,</br>The landskips to deluge in show'rs,</br>Or mists o'er the cottages bend,</br>Consigning to dulness the hours:</br>Yet sorrow disturbs not the soul,</br>Content for her residence forms,</br>Altho' in the far distant pole</br>Extends the rough blast of the storms.

Content come with visage serene,</br>Thy blessings unfold to my view,</br>Attendant be innocence seen,</br>I want not the wealth of Peru.</br>The bosom of calmness is thine;</br>The Virtues in modest array,</br>Thy presents are ever benign,</br>Thy song is the music of May.

Pastora inspire my reed,</br>Can sounds more harmonious flow,</br>From encomiums more justly proceed,</br>Than those which to Delia I owe.</br>For now the fair morning appears,</br>My muse with inchantment to wing,</br>Another we add to her years,</br>'Tis the birth-day of Delia I sing.

Tho' naked and brown are the lawns,</br>And winter still harrows the day,</br>Aurora transcendently dawns,</br>For Delia has heighten'd her ray.</br>For her, with each grace in her train,</br>Shall spring in fresh beauty appear,</br>The summer's varieties reign,</br>And winter no longer appear.

Prophetic, methinks, that my song</br>Has called up the earth-chearing breeze,</br>The birds am'rous ditties prolong,</br>The turtles soft coo in the trees.</br>Each warbler the symphony hails,</br>And harmony gentle creates,</br>'Tis Cupid my fair one prevails,</br>On their musical nuptials awaits.

A chaplet I'll weave for the morn,</br>The myrtle soft verdure bespreads,</br>Flora wakens the wreath to adorn,</br>And rises wherever she treads.</br>Let Delia approve my fond lays,</br>Accept of the garland I twine,</br>My brow shall be cover'd with bays,</br>In honour of her Valentine.</br>
